definitions.definition: the rate at which something happens or is repeated

examples.text: Fatal road accidents have decreased in frequency over recent years.
Dawn was then visiting New York **with increasing frequency**.
a society with a **high/low frequency** *(= happening often/not very often)* of stable marriages
Users will be able to rearrange their icons by frequency of use.
The program can show us **word frequency** *(= how often words occur in a language)*.
Crime can increase in frequency in less settled neighbourhoods.
The drug can reduce the frequency and severity of attacks.
These incidents have increased in frequency.

definitions.definition: the fact of something happening often

examples.text: the alarming frequency of computer errors
The relative frequency of this illness in the area is of concern to all doctors.
Objects like this turn up at sales with surprising frequency.
Bullets bounced off the rock with alarming frequency.

definitions.definition: the rate at which a sound or electromagnetic wave vibrates (= moves up and down)

examples.text: Electromagnetic waves of **radio frequency** can make molecules vibrate and heat up.

definitions.definition: the number of radio waves for every second of a radio signal

examples.text: There are only a limited number of broadcasting frequencies.

wordOrigin: mid 16th cent. (gradually superseding late Middle English frequence; originally denoting a gathering of people): from Latin frequentia, from frequens, frequent- ‘crowded, frequent’.
